title: 113_s643
content: The Act titled "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" aims to enhance cost savings. The Act "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" is amended to include the identification of surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority by agency employees, which must be referred to the Chief Financial Officer along with recommendations from the Inspector General. The Act "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" now requires agency employees to report surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority to the Chief Financial Officer for potential rescission, with transfers to the general fund if deemed effective by the agency head. Transfers are exempt from Title X of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The Act "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" mandates agency heads to transfer surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority to the Treasury's general fund for deficit reduction. Transfers are not subject to Title X of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The agency head can retain up to 10% of the transferred amounts for cash awards. The agency head can retain up to 10% of surplus funds for cash awards to employees who identified them. An annual report must be submitted to the Office of Personnel Management detailing any fraud, waste, or savings achieved through employee disclosures. The agency head must report on employee disclosures of fraud, waste, and savings, including total savings and cash awards given. This information is included in the agency's budget request to the Office of Management and Budget. The Office of Personnel Management submits an annual report to Congress and the Government Accountability Office. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management ensures agency compliance with the cash award program and submits an annual certification to Congress. The Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013 requires a report every 3 years on Federal cost savings and awards. The Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013 mandates agencies to comply with cash award programs and requires the Comptroller General to report on cost savings and awards every 3 years. Officers eligible for cash awards are defined under Section 4509 of title 5, United States Code. Section 4509 of title 5, United States Code, prohibits cash awards to certain officers, including those at level I of the Executive Schedule, agency heads, and members of independent establishments. The table of sections for chapter 45 is amended accordingly. Prohibition of cash awards to certain officers at level I of the Executive Schedule, agency heads, and members of independent establishments.
